awd_titl_txt: Acquisition of a State-of-the-Art 40Ar/39Ar Geochronology System for the AGES Lab at Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory
awd_abstract_narration:
Analytical facilities for dating geological materials are important for education, research and economic and petroleum geology exploration. The AGES (Argon Geochronology for Earth Sciences) laboratory at Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory was established in 1997, and actively contributes to all of these goals working with both academic and industry colleagues. This award will provide funding to acquire a new-generation noble gas mass spectrometer and pumps for its extraction line to set up a state-of-the art instrument for high precision measurements of Argon isotopes that permit dating of geological materials. This improved capability provides extraordinary opportunities for improving our understanding of Earth's history of climate variability, biological evolution and mountain-building processes. The training of students in analytical procedures and geochronology methods will be greatly enhanced by access to state-of-the-art instrumentation. 

Over the past several years, the advent of a new generation of noble gas mass spectrometers for Ar-Ar dating is greatly improving the precision with which small samples can be analyzed. Such improvements are critical for the goal of sequencing Earth History with a seamlessly integrated Ar-Ar : U-Pb : astrochronology time-scale and for probing important events in Earth's history such as extinctions, dramatic climate changes and evolutionary pathways. This funding will allow the purchase of a state-of-the-art noble gas instrument as well as peripheral parts for building an extraction line for introducing samples to the instrument. The AGES lab at LDEO has been an active participant in EARTHTIME activities that are dedicated towards the goal of accurately sequencing Earth history. The upgrade that will come from the acquisition of this new generation of instrument will transform the ability to continue to be actively involved in EARTHTIME while also continuing to train students and post docs and serve a large collaborative user base.

por.por_cntn:
The new state-of-the-art noble gas mass spectrometer for Ar-Ar geochronology is now installed in room 14 of the Gary C Comer Geochemistry building at Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory. This new instrumentation represents a significant advance in our capabilities to date very young volcanic samples and to obtain very precise ages on older samples as well. The significance of this advance is multi-fold. The instrumentation will serve researchers and students at Columbia, in the New York City region and nationally and internationally, and will be a significant resource for educating the next generation of Earth Scientists. There are several aspects of the new developments that are exciting for basic Earth Sciences as well as being beneficial for society. By being able to date young volcanic rocks very reliably, we can contribute to understanding the natural hazards represented by volcanic eruptions – that is by documenting the recurrence interval of the eruptions. Additionally, the ability to date young volcanics will contribute to the calibration of cosmogenic surface exposure dating - by determining the exposure time of volcanic flows, the production rate of cosmogenic isotopes can be determined. Cosmogenic surface exposure dating uses the nuclides that have been formed by cosmic ray exposure since a rock came to the surface of the Earth. This has importance for understanding landscape evolution. And it also has importance for constraining the history of Earth’s glaciers which is important for document how glaciers respond to climate variations – also important for sea level history.

In addition to the advancements in dating young volcanic rocks, the new instrumentation will allow obtaining very highly precise Ar-Ar dates on older crystals that can contribute to our ongoing goals of improving geochronometers in Earth History. This is important because it allows us to sequence Earth History events with fine enough resolution to test hypotheses of causes and effects of events such as major volcanic eruptions, meteorite impacts, mass extinctions, and biological evolution.

The instrument is also capable of high quality Ne isotope measurements, and this can contribute to goals of calibrating cosmogenic surface exposure dating as well as the geologic history of regions and their landscape evolution.
